Kamal Ahmed wrote:

> Since I did not follow completely what the recipe was, are these two
> approaches same?

They are similar. They also point to an observation I've made about 
abstract classes, explaining why I prefer not to use them.

Every abstract class consists of two parts: the abstract part and the 
concrete part. The concrete part consists of all the fields and methods 
with implementations (bodies). The abstract part consists of all the 
declarations of abstract methods.

I recommend splitting (most) abstract classes into a concrete class and 
an interface. Test the interface using the recipe you cited. Test the 
concrete class with interaction-style tests faking and mocking the 
interface, as needed.

The concrete class will probably take an instance of the interface 
through its constructor.

I know you probably can't change the design of the code you're testing, 
but if you can, consider giving this technique a go.

Take care.
----
This is the first time I can see value in the test case class not 
extending a JUnit framework class. We could use the Self-Shunt pattern 
where the test case class provides implementations for the abstract 
methods, extending the abstract class. There would probably be one class 
per different way to fake the abstract methods. This corresponds pretty 
well to different test case classes for different fixtures, in general. 
If I had a good, concrete example for this, I could write an article.
